docx_questions.text: What term is used to describe the capacity of some erythrocytes to vary in size, especially in relationship to some anemias?
What is the fundamental physiologic manifestation of anemia?
The paresthesia that occurs in vitNamURinSIBN1G2TdBe.fCiOciMency anemia is a result of which of the following?
options: Reduction in acetylcholine receptors in the postsynaptic nerves
Myelin degeneration in the spinal cord
estruction of myelin in peripheral nerves
ltered function of neurons in the parietal lobe

docx_questions.text: Which of the following describes how the body compensates for anemia?
options: Increasing rate and depth of breathing
Hemoglobin holding more firmly onto oxygen

docx_questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a megaloblastic anemia?
Deficiencies in folate and vitamin B12 alter the synthesis of which of the following?
The underlying disorder of whichNaUneRmSIiNaGisTBa.CreOsMult of the defective secretion of the intrinsic factor, which is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12?
After a person has a subtotal gastrectomy for chronic gastritis, which type of anemia will result?
What causes the atrophy of gastric mucosal cells that result in pernicious anemia?
Which statement best describes a Schilling test?
options: dministration of radioactive cobalamin and the measurement of its excretion in the urine to test for vitamin B12 deficiency
Measurement of antigen-antibody immune complexes in the blood to test for hemolytic anemia
Measurement of serum ferritin and total iron-binding capacity in the blood to test for iron deficiency anemia
dministration of folate and measurement in 2 hours of its level in a blood sample to test for folic acid deficiency anemia.

docx_questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for pernicious anemia (PA)?
Which condition resulting from untreated pernicious anemia (PA) is fatal?
How is the effectiveness of vitamin B12 therapy measured?
Which statement about folic acid is false?
options: Folic acid absorption is dependent on the enzyme folacin.
Folic acid is stored in the liver.
Folic acid is essential for RNA and DNA synthesis within erythrocytes.
Folic acid is absorbed in the upper small intestine.

docx_questions.text: Which anemia produces small, pale erythrocytes?
Which type of anemia is characterized by fatigue, weakness, and dyspnea, as well as conjunctiva of the eyes and brittle, concave nails?
What is the most common cause of iron deficiency anemia (IDA)?
Continued therapy of pernicious anemia (PA) generally lasts how long?
options: Until the iron level is normal

docx_questions.text: Sideroblastic anemia can occasionally result from an autosomal recessive transmission inherited from which relative?
Clinical manifestations of mild-to-moderate splenomegaly and hepatomegaly, bronze-colored skin, and cardiac dysrhythmias are indicative of which anemia?
Considering sideroblastic anemia, what would be the expected effect on the plasma iron levels?
options: Plasma iron levels would be high.
Levels would be only minimally affected.

docx_questions.text: In aplastic anemia (AA), pancytopenia develops as a result of which of the following?
options: Suppression of erythropoietin to produce adequate amounts of erythrocytes
Suppression of the bone marrow to produce adequate amounts of erythrocytes, leukocytes, and thrombocytes
Lack of DNA to form sufficient quantities of erythrocytes, leukocytes, and thrombocytes
Lack of stem cells to form sufficient quantities of leukocytes

docx_questions.text: What is the most common pathophysiologic process that triggers aplastic anemia (AA)?
options: utoimmune disease against hematopoiesis by activated cytotoxic T (Tc) cells
Malignancy of the bone marrow in which unregulated proliferation of erythrocytes crowd out other blood cells
utoimmune disease against hematopoiesis by activated immunoglobulins
Inherited genetic disorder with recessive X-linked transmission

docx_questions.text: An allogenic bone marrow transplantation remains the preferred method for treating which anemia?
Which statement is true regarding warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia?
options: Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia occurs primarily in men.
It is self-limiting and rarely produces hemolysis.
Erythrocytes are bound to macrophages and sequestered in the spleen.
Immunoglobulin M coats erythrocytes and binds them to receptors on monocytes.

docx_questions.text: When considering hemolytic anemia, which statement is true regarding the occurrence of jaundice?
options: Erythrocytes are destroyed in the spleen.
Heme destruction exceeds the liver’s ability to conjugate and excrete bilirubin.
The patient has elevations in aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT).
The erythrocytes are coated with an immunoglobulin.

docx_questions.text: Erythrocyte life span of less than 120 days, ineffective bone marrow response to erythropoietin, and altered iron metabolism describe the pathophysiologic characteristics of which type of anemia?
What is the primary cause of the symptoms of polycythemia vera?
Treatment for polycythemia vera involves which of the following?
options: Restoration of blood volume by plasma expanders

docx_questions.text: Considering iron replacement therapy prescribed for iron deficiency anemia, who is likely to require long-term daily maintenance dosage?
options: woman who has not yet experienced menopause
teenager who is involved in strenuous athletics
middle-aged man who smokes two packs of cigarettes a day
n older person demonstrating signs of dementia

docx_questions.text: Which statement is true regarding the physical manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency anemia?
options: Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia seldom results in neurologic symptoms.
The chances of a cure are good with appropriate treatment.
The condition is reversible in 75% of the cases.
Symptoms are a result of demyelination.
